nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market movements and help investors make better buy/sell decisions
A systematic literature review (SLR) methodology was used to collect and synthesize prior research on stock market prediction with machine learning
Search process: digital libraries (Elsevier, ACM, IEEE, Google Scholar) yielded 550 papers, screened by title, abstract, full text, resulting in 45 included papers

Commonly used machine learning algorithms for stock prediction reported in the literature include linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest

Common input attributes used to train models include market history, news and event information, public mood (social media), commodity and fuel prices, interest rates, foreign exchange, technical indicators (SMA, ARIMA), oil, gold, silver, and Twitter data
Multiple studies report that support vector machines perform well for predicting stock movement and often outperform other classifiers in specific experiments

Random forest has been reported to achieve high accuracy in some studies (reported examples: 83% accuracy in Khan et al., 64% in Gholamian and Davoodi), indicating variable but potentially strong performance
An example multi-classifier study reported 65% accuracy, and authors noted accuracy can be improved by using more effective attributes and larger training datasets

Combining event knowledge extracted from news with machine learning models, especially neural networks, has been shown to increase prediction accuracy (reported increase about five percent in one study)
Accurate stock price prediction helps investors decide when to buy at low prices and sell at high prices, potentially increasing profit and reducing investment risk
Stock market prediction is challenging because stock values change dynamically and are affected by many events and macroeconomic factors
Standard training procedure: collect historical data with chosen attributes, preprocess and extract event/text features, train supervised ML models and evaluate predictive accuracy

The literature contains multiple applied studies mapping specific algorithms to tasks: SVM applied to next-day forecasting, neural networks trained on market indicators and news, genetic algorithms used for direction prediction, kNN applied for event prediction
Limitation: Many external and interacting factors (news, macroeconomics, events) limit predictive accuracy and make consistent high performance difficult; human judgment alone is insufficient

Conclusion: Machine learning is a useful set of tools for stock market prediction; synthesizing extant studies clarifies common algorithms, attributes, and challenges to guide future work and practitioners
